S2095-4956(17)30765-9 10.1016/j.jechem.2017.09.014 Science Press Fig. 1 Scheme for the NGF and SNG fabrication: NGF with uniform doping of bulk nitrogen atoms fabricated by CH4 and pyridine simultaneously induced during CVD, while SNG with surface enriched nitrogen was obtained through the post pyridine pyrolysis after graphene deposition on MgO template. The SNG is with surface nitrogen doping on continuous 3D graphene framework. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Characterization of the MgO, MgO@NGF, and MgO@SNG. (a) SEM image and TFM image (inset) of the MgO; (b) TEM image and (c) high resolution TEM image of the MgO@NGF; (d) RD spectra of the MgO, MgO@NGF, MgO@SNG and standard MgO XRD patterns (JCPDS No. 45-0946). Fig 2 Fig. 3 Morphological characterization of the NGF and SNG. (a) SEM image, (b) TEM image and (c) high resolution TEM image of the NGF; (d) SEM image, (e) TEM image and (f) high resolution TEM image of the SNG. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Surface chemistry of the NGF and SNG reflected by the N1s fine scan spectra of NGF (top) and SNG (bottom). Fig 4 Fig. 5 Characterization on the NGF and SNG. (a) N2 isotherms of the NGF and SNG; (b) pore size distributions derived from isothermal adsorption plots; (c) Raman spectra and (d) TGA curves, differential plots (inset) of the NGF and SNG. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The ORR performance of 3D metal-free graphene based electrocatalysts. (a) Disk current densities (bottom) and the corresponding ring current densities (top) of NGF and SNG catalysts on RRDE in O2-saturated 0.10 mol L−1 KOH solution; (b) the electron transfer number of the NGF and SNG catalysts based on the corresponding RRDE data in (a), the inset exhibited the possible reaction pathways of ORR in aqueous alkaline electrolyte. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Li−S battery performance of NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes. (a) The cycling performance and (b) galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes; (c) the rate performance of NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes. Fig 7 Fig. 8 The cycling performance of Li−S batteries with flexible NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes with high areal sulfur loading. Beijing Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Reaction Engineering and Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China The introduction of nitrogen heteroatoms into carbon materials is a facile and efficient strategy to regulate their reactivities and facilitate their potential applications in energy conversion and storage. However, most of nitrogen heteroatoms are doped into the bulk phase of carbon without site selectivity, which significantly reduces the contacts of feedstocks with the active dopants in a conductive scaffold. Herein we proposed the chemical vapor deposition of a nitrogen-doped graphene skin on the 3D porous graphene framework and donated the carbon/carbon composite as surface N-doped grapheme (SNG). In contrast with routine N-doped graphene framework (NGF) with bulk distribution of N heteroatoms, the SNG renders a high surface N content of 1.81 at%, enhanced electrical conductivity of 31 S cm−1, a large surface area of 1531 m2 g−1, a low defect density with a low I D/I G ratio of 1.55 calculated from Raman spectrum, and a high oxidation peak of 532.7 °C in oxygen atmosphere. The selective distribution of N heteroatoms on the surface of SNG affords the effective exposure of active sites at the interfaces of the electrode/electrolyte, so that more N heteroatoms are able to contact with oxygen feedstocks in oxygen reduction reaction or serve as polysulfide anchoring sites to retard the shuttle of polysulfides in a lithium–sulfur battery. This work opens a fresh viewpoint on the manipulation of active site distribution in a conductive scaffolds for multi-electron redox reaction based energy conversion and storage. Graphical abstract The selective distribution of nitrogen heteroatoms on the surface of graphene materials affords effective exposure of active sites at the interfaces of the electrode/electrolyte in oxygen reduction reaction and lithium–sulfur batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-doped graphene Chemical vapor deposition Oxygen reduction reaction Lithium–sulfur battery Porous carbon materials Exposure of active sites 1 Introduction Nanocarbon materials (e.g., graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs)) exhibiting superior intrinsic physical properties have been widely applied in the area of energy storage, composites, catalysis, and devices, etc. [1–4]. With tunable chemical characteristic, the structure and performance of nanocarbon can be further modulated through surface modification, chemical functionalization, and heteroatom doping [5–8]. For instance, the integration of N atoms into sp 2 nanocarbon materials can effectively regulate the surrounding chemical environment, which is a versatile method to modulate their polarity and reactivity [9,10]. The one-step chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and one-pot reduction of graphene oxide is widely applied for the fabrication of nitrogen-doped carbon materials [11–13]. However, the nitrogen heteroatoms are always distributed into the bulk phase, in which case only small amount of the heteroatoms are directly exposed to the surface. It should be mentioned that most of catalysis reactions and chemical adsorption are only happened on active sites that exposed at the interfaces of catalysts and feedstocks [14]. Therefore, some heteroatoms cannot participate into reactions and render few contributions for the overall reactivity. In fact, the heteroatom doping can be manipulated by materials processing with the heteroatom-free carbon served as the template for doped carbon formation. For instance, a hybrid of sulfur doped carbon aerogel and graphite oxide were proposed by Bandosz and co-workers through a self-assembly process for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) with good tolerance to methanol crossover [15]. Zhang and co-workers [12] reported the use of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as axis and N-doped carbon as skins to achieve an N-doped carbon coaxial nanocable with surface-enriched nitrogen doping (denoted as CNT@NCNT). In contrast to one-step synthesized NCNTs containing inaccessible N-doped inner walls, the CNT@NCNT composed with the pristine CNTs as the core and the N-doped carbon layers as the shell, which render active sites fully exposed for highly efficient electrocatalysis and inner continuous CNT walls well preserved for rapid electron transport. The CNTs are encapsulated by porous carbon that affords more space to accommodate ions and feedstocks in electrocatalysis [16], supercapacitors [17], and rechargeable batteries [18]. The coating of mesoporous carbon with a microporous shell is effective to accommodate the polysulfide intermediates [18], which can significantly enhance the sulfur utilization and extend the cycling life of a lithium–sulfur (Li–S) battery. In this contribution, we fabricated a nitrogen-doped graphene skin on the 3D porous graphene framework (denoted as SNG in this work). The motivation on the use of graphene as the support was attributed from their unique porous structure, interconnected conductive pathways, and abundant free space. However, the one-step doped porous graphene with high doping level is always with poor electrical conductivity. To probe the importance of rational nitrogen doping at materials scale, two kinds of nitrogen-doped graphene framework were proposed herein (Fig. 1 ). The first one is 3D porous graphene framework with N atoms uniformly distributed in bulk, which was defined as NGF and was fabricated through CVD growth with CH4 and pyridine simultaneously as precursors on MgO template. The other one is the SNG, in which graphene was first fabricated with CH4 as precursor on MgO surface and N-doped graphene skin was then attached on the preceding graphene layers. The electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), gravimetric elemental analysis, nitrogen physisorption, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and Raman spectroscopy were employed to probe the nitrogen distribution and related structures. Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and Li−S battery are selected as typical systems for the demonstration of their energy applications. The significance on rational nitrogen doping of 3D porous graphene framework is also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis The MgO template was synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction using the commercial MgO powders as raw materials [19,20]. Typically, 7.0 g MgO powders (99.5%) and 700 mL deionized water were added into a 2000 mL glass flask (equipped with a reflux condenser) and was kept at 100°C under continuous strong stirring for 12.0 h. Following that, the suspension was maintained without stirring at 100°C for 12.0 h. The final MgO templates were obtained after filtering, washing, 105°C-drying of the above suspension, and calcination at 500 °C for 5.0 h. 3D porous graphene was synthesized via CVD method with the as-above MgO as templates and methane/pyridine as carbon/nitrogen source, respectively. The porous MgO templates were high-temperature (900°C) calcined in a horizontal quartz tube reactor under flowing Ar (200 mL min−1). The NGF was CVD self-assembled on porous oxide templates by simultaneous introduction of CH4 (600 mL min−1) and pyridine (1 mL h−1). The reaction was maintained for 10 min before the furnace was cooled to room temperature under Ar protection. As for the fabrication of SNG, the CH4 (600 mL min−1) was firstly introduced for 10 min graphene deposition, then the furnace was cooled to 750 °C and maintained for 10 min with the injection of pyridine (1 mL h−1). After deposition of nitrogen-doped carbon on MgO@G surface, the furnace was cooled to room temperature under Ar protection. The raw products (MgO@NGF and MgO@SNG) were purified by HCl (5.0 mol L−1) aqueous solution at 80 °C for 12.0 h to fully remove the templates. After filtering, washing, 105 °C-drying and slight grind, both the purified NGF and SNG were finally obtained. 2.2 Fabrication of 3D porous graphene-S cathodes The SNG-S and NGF-S composites were prepared by a facile melt-diffusion strategy. Typically, a mixture containing 30 wt% SNG/NGF and 70 wt% sulfur powder was strongly grinded in an agate mortar for 10 min. To completely incorporate the sulfur into the micro-/mesopores of the SNG/NGF, the as-obtained mixture was then placed in a sealed quartz bottle and heated at 155 °C for 4.0 h. The traditional 3D porous graphene-S electrode with Al foil as the current collector was fabricated by a facile slurry-coating procedure. The SNG/NGF-S cathode slurry was prepared by mixing the SNG/NGF-S nanocomposites (80 wt%), CNT conductive agents (10 wt%), and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) binder (10 wt%) in an N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) solvent dispersant. Positive electrodes were produced by blade coating the slurry onto aluminum foil and drying at 60 °C for 12.0 h. 13.0 mm-diameter disks with an areal sulfur loading of ca. 1.7 mg cm−2 were punched as the working electrodes for Li−S cells. The flexible 3D porous graphene-S electrode was fabricated by a shearing dispersion-filtration method. Super-long aligned CNTs with a length of ca. 4.0 mm and a diameter of 30–40 nm were fabricated by floating catalyst CVD. 30.0 mg of super-long CNTs were dispersed in sulfur-saturated ethanol solution and kept shearing for 3.0 min in an ice bath. 72.0 mg of SNG/NGF-S composite materials were added to above-mentioned suspension and further sheared for another 1.0 min. The whole dispersion was filtrated to obtain a flexible paper electrode with an areal sulfur loading of ca. 4.0 mg cm−2. After that, the film was dried at 60 °C for 12.0 h. 13.0 mm-diameter disks were punched as the working electrodes for Li−S cells. 2.3 Structure characterizations The morphology of samples were characterized by a JSM 7401F field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL, Japan) at 3.0 kV and a JEM 2010 high solution transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL, Japan) at 120.0 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Cu-K α radiation source (Bruker, USA). Raman spectra of the graphene samples were collected with an He–Ne laser excitation at 633 nm using LabRAM HR800 Raman spectrophotometer (Horiba Jobin Yvon, France). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed by the TGA/DSC1 STARe system (Mettler Toledo, Switzerland) with a temperature ramp rate of 20 °C min−1 and O2 flow rate of 50 mL min−1. N2 isotherms were obtained at −196 °C (77 K) with a volumetric Autosorb-IQ2-MP-C system (Quantachrome, USA). The specific surface area (SSA) was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore size distributions were calculated using the quenched solid density functional theory (DFT) method from the adsorption branches of the N2 isotherms. Before the physisorption measurements, the sample was degassed at 300 °C for 10.0 h to avoid the influence of impurities. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) operated by EscaLab 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA) was employed to investigate the surface chemistry of the samples. The gravimetric elemental analysis was performed on a Vario EL III Elemental Analyzer (Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH, Germany). The amounts of H/C/N/O were calculated through thermal conductivity detector (TCD) of the sufficient combustion products (H2O, CO2, and NO2). The four-probe method was performed to determine the powder conductivity of NGF/SNG, which were compressed into a dense disk with 13.0 mm-diameter under a pressure of 8.0 MPa. 2.4 Electrocatalytic performance evaluation The evaluation of the electrocatalytic performance of all the samples was carried out in a three-electrode electrochemical cell with a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and a platinum foil as the reference electrode and the counter electrode, respectively. The graphene samples were loaded onto the glass carbon electrode to serve as the working electrode with the same mass loading of 254.8 μg cm−2. Typically, 5.0 mg catalyst was dispersed in a mixture solution of 1.0 mL ethanol and 10.0 μL Nafion solution (5.0 wt%) by ultrasonication. 10.0 μL of the catalyst solution was pipetted onto the glass carbon electrode with a diameter of 5.0 mm. Then 5.0 μL diluted Nafion (1.0 wt%) was coated on the electrode surface after the evaporation of solvent and the electrode was dried in an oven for 30 min at 60 °C before use. The evaluation tests were performed at room temperature using 0.10 mol L−1 O2-saturated KOH as electrolyte. A CHI 760D electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China) was employed to record the data. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) voltammogram measurements were conducted on an RRDE configuration (Pine Research Instrument, USA). The disk electrode was scanned cathodically at 10.0 mV s−1 and the potential of the ring electrode was set as +0.5 V constantly. The electron transfer number n was determined as followed: (1) n = 4 I d I d + I r / N where I d is disk current, I r is ring current and N is current collection efficiency of the Pt ring which was determined to be 0.26. 2.5 Electrochemical performance evaluation The standard 2025 coin-type cells were employed for electrochemical performance evaluation of 3D porous graphene-S electrodes. The electrolyte was 1.0 mol•L−1 lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (EGDME, volume ratio 1:1). 1.0-mm-thick lithium metal foil was applied as the anode and the Celgard 2400 membranes were acted as the separator. The Li−S cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove-box with electrolyte amount of 8.0 μL mg−1 S. The cyclic performance was collected by multi-channel battery cycler (Wuhan LAND electronics, China) within a voltage window of 1.7−2.8 V. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nitrogen doping of 3D porous graphene on porous oxide templates MgO flakes were adopted as mesoporous catalysts for templated growth of 3D porous N-doped graphene. MgO flakes exhibited hexagon morphology with size of hundreds nm scale (Fig. 2 a). Because of high thermal stability, MgO were selected as effective templates for CVD growth of graphene framework [20–23]. Taken NGF as an example, after calcination and further CH4/pyridine-CVD, the as-obtained MgO@NGF composites maintained similar plate-like morphology with MgO flakes (Fig. 2b). Such porous template flakes were assembled with MgO nanocubes, which can be distinguished even after high-temperature reaction without any collapse or crystal reforming. Perfect alignment of the (200) lattice with a d-spacing of 0.21 nm unambiguously indicated the MgO phase, where the deposited ultrathin N-doped graphene layers tightly wrapped on the fringe of template structural unit (Fig. 2c). According to graphitization nature on MgO, the wrinkles of N-doped graphene sheets were induced by each individual sheet's squeeze and overlap. The topological defects generated more easily on oxide templates [24], especially under harsh condition when nitrogen source induced [23,25]. Only 1−2 layers of N-doped graphene were detected on MgO. The XRD spectrum of MgO@NGF was in accordance with that of MgO (Fig. 2d), meanwhile the characteristic diffraction peak of graphite at 26.4° was indiscernible, confirming the few-layer nature of deposited graphene. The MgO templates were completely removed by the HCl treatment. The as-obtained NGF aggregated into powder, while each graphene flake was clearly identified (Fig. 3 a and b). The NGF flake exhibited similar hexagon morphology and composed of hundreds of graphene nanocubes conformally inherited from structural unit of MgO (Figs. 2b and 3b). The size of graphene nanocubes was 8−15 nm, a little bit shrink from NGF deposited on MgO (Fig. 3c). However, the high curvature and 3D interconnection of interior graphene prevented the NGF from stacking. Such confined mesopore spaces were desirable for applications in electrochemical energy storage. In contrast, a post pyridine CVD was employed for the formation of N-doped graphene on MgO@G (gained from CH4-CVD process, Fig. 1). Consistency of XRD spectra between MgO@SNG and MgO@NGF revealed the N-doped graphene layer deposited on MgO@G is very thin (Fig. 2d). The SNG obtained after purification of templates presented similar morphology with that of NGF (Fig. 3d–f). 3.2 The difference between NGF and SNG Hardly distinguished from morphology in bulk samples, the differences between NGF and SNG were further detected by XPS, gravimetric elemental analysis, N2 physisorption, Raman spectra, and TGA. Both the chemical and physical properties were extracted for comparison between NGF and SNG. In order to confirm the doping of N atoms in graphene layer, the surface/bulk chemistry of as-obtained materials were firstly probed by XPS and elemental analysis. The bulk compositions of NGF/SNG were validated through the gravimetric elemental analysis in macroscopic quantity (Table 1 ). Around 1.30 wt% nitrogen was successfully doped in graphene samples. The relative abundance of nitrogen on the surface of NGF/SNG was listed as Table 1. Notably, the atomic N C−1 ratio determined by XPS (0.019) was higher than that determined by elemental analysis (0.012) for SNG, indicating that the N atoms were concentrated on external surface of interconnected graphene network. In contrast, the N C−1 ratio for NGF determined by XPS (0.012) was in accordance with that determined by elemental analysis (0.012), which indicated a uniform distribution of N atoms in graphene framework. Except the different deposition positions of nitrogen source, the compositions of N-containing functional groups were modulated between NGF and SNG (Table 2 ). The N 1s fine scan spectra (Fig. 4 ) were deconvoluted into four peaks which were assigned to pyridinic N (398.4 eV), pyrrolic N (400.1 eV), quaternary N (401.2 eV), and oxidized N (402.9 eV), respectively. Due to the high-temperature (900 °C) CH4/pyridine co-deposition, N atoms incorporated in the growth of NGF graphene layer yielded higher quaternary N proportion than that of SNG (Table 2). As for the pyridine deposition on surface of MgO@G, it was not easy to form quaternary N with limited supply of carbon source, while more N-doped edge sites (pyridinic N and pyrrolic N) were founded. The preservation of pyrrolic N in SNG was ascribed to the lower post N-doping temperature (750 °C) [26]. N-containing functional groups in nanocarbon materials could be further regulated by changing the space velocity of the nitrogen precursor and the ratio of carbon source and nitrogen source. In both NGF and SNG, N atoms were well dispersed to activate the surrounding C atoms, giving the promising catalytic activity for ORR process. The N2 physisorption test was employed for porous structure characterization. The N2 isotherms of both NGF and SNG exhibited a sharp increase at p/p 0 < 0.05 and a dominant hysteresis loop at p/p 0 > 0.35, indicating a hierarchically micro- and mesoporous structure (Fig. 5 a). The defects, wrinkles, and functional groups of graphene contributed to the adsorbing capacity at low relative pressure (p/p 0 < 0.05), while the adsorbing volume increment thereafter was contributed by mesopores (confined mesopore spaces in/among graphene nanocubes, 0.05 < p/p 0 < 0.95) and open macropores (intervals among graphene flakes, p/p 0 > 0.95). The CH4/pyridine co-deposition made NGF own more structural defects on graphene framework than SNG gained from post N-doping process, so the NGF had a higher content of micropores (pore size < 2 nm) (Fig. 5b) and larger adsorbing volume at p/p 0 < 0.05. What's more, the porous graphene framework rendered confined space in nanocubes of NGF more accessible to the N2 molecules. Therefore, the detectable mesopores’ proportion increased (Fig. 5b) which induced the rise of adsorbing volume (p/p 0 > 0.05) of NGF larger than that of SNG (Fig. 5a). Both NGF and SNG exhibit high SSA of 1732 and 1531 m2 g−1, respectively, indicating the non-stacked few (1–3) layer nature of NGF and SNG. Note these SSA values are higher than most of 3D porous N-doped graphene prepared by a solution-based route with graphene oxide (GO) reduction process (100–1200 m2 g−1) [27]. Raman signals are very sensitive to the degree of structural disorder, giving useful information on the defects of 3D porous graphene materials. NGF exhibited high intensity ratio of D band to G band (I D/I G = 1.80), which was associated with the presence of a large quantity of wrinkles and curves in graphene framework and structural point defects induced by N-doping (Fig. 5c). As for the SNG, whose interconnected graphene network was grown without interference of pyridine decomposition, had less structural defects and lower I D/I G ratio of 1.55 (Fig. 5c). However, such I D/I G ratios reported herein are much higher than those of graphene grown on Cu/Si/Ni substrate (I D/I G ratio of 0.03−1.2) [28,29], vermiculite (I D/I G ratio of 0.94) [30], MgO with large crystalline grain (hundreds nm scale, I D/I G ratio of 1.13) [23] or with deposition of ferrocene (I D/I G ratio of 0.85) [22]. Meanwhile, both NGF and SNG exhibited the same low ratio of 2D band to G band (I 2D/I G) with 0.24. The broad 2D band revealed the overlapped graphene layers of NGF/SNG are not AB-Bernal stacking, while the weak intensity of 2D band indicated their few (1−3) layer nature, in good consistence with the TEM observation (Fig. 3c and f). TGA measurements in O2 atmosphere were performed to evaluate O2 combustion resistant of 3D porous N-doped graphene. Compared with NGF, the weight loss curve of SNG shifted to the high temperature zone, indicating that the SNG was more resistant to the O2 combustion reaction (Fig. 5d). The differential plots of thermogravimetric curves reflected weight loss rate during the test (inset Fig. 5d). The peak values of differential plots appeared at 514.7 °C (NGF) and 532.7 °C (SNG), respectively. Such improvement was attributed to the higher SSA and more structural defects of NGF than that of SNG. In combination of the results through XPS, gravimetric elemental analysis, N2 physisorption, Raman spectra, and TGA, the post-injection of nitrogen source rendered the N heteroatoms gathered on the surface of SNG and kept the interconnected porous graphene network containing fewer defects than NGF with bulk N-doping from CH4/pyridine co-deposition process. As a result, the electrical conductivity of SNG (31 S cm−1) determined by the four probe method was higher than that of NGF (23 S cm−1). With such high electrical conductivity, the as-obtained 3D porous N-doped graphene materials were employed as the robust conductive scaffold for electrochemical energy storage applications. 3.3 The electrocatalytic performance of NGF and SNG N-doped nanocarbon materials exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for the ORR, which is essential for renewable energy technologies such as alkaline polymer electrolyte fuel cell, metal-air batteries, and water splitting cells [31–35]. In this contribution, ORR was selected as the probe reaction to detect structure–function relationship of NGF/SNG, as the ORR activity of N-functionalized nanocarbons is generally ascribed to (1) the charge delocalization or spin-polarization of the sp 2-hybridized carbon lattice covalently embedded with the dopants [36]; (2) carbon nanostructures with edges, dangling bonds, and topological defects as high-energy sites for charge redistribution [24,37–39]. The association between the N-containing functional groups, structural defects of NGF/SNG and their ORR electrocatalysis was established with the structural and chemical information. Fig. 6 (a) revealed the linear sweep voltammetry profiles on a RRDE. The onset potential of NGF electrode (−0.140 V) was 14 mV positively shifted compared with that of SNG electrode (−0.154 V). What's more, the higher ORR current density of NGF electrode before −0.284 V than that of SNG electrode was ascribed to the larger SSA and higher quaternary N proportion of NGF catalyst than that of SNG electrocatalyst. Although the electron-donating quaternary N sites were favorable for ORR [40] in aqueous alkaline electrolyte, the synergistic effect with different active sites, electron pathways, and multi-phase interfaces should not be ignored. After the crossover potential of −0.284 V, SNG with surface enriched N atoms and larger electrical conductivity exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity for ORR in comparison with the equably bulk N-doped graphene framework (NGF). The electron transfer number per O2 (n) is determined from the RRDE profiles (Fig. 6b). Both SNG and NGF exhibited a similar n (around 3.34) over the potential range from −0.2 to −1.0 V, suggesting a dominant 4-electron pathway of ORR on the 3D porous N-doped graphene catalysts. Although both SNG and NGF were composed of few (1–3) layer graphene and similar bulk N content (around 1.30 wt%, Table 1), the SNG with more surface N heteroatoms deliver a much high ORR reactivity when the applied voltage was less than −0.3 V. 3.4 The Li−S cathodes performance of NGF and SNG The emerging Li−S battery technology with excellent theoretical specific energy of 2600 Wh kg−1 had attracted wide interests [41–46]. Within the redox chemistry of sulfur in cathode, the circulation of solid (S8)–liquid (polysulfides, S4-8 2−)–solid (Li2S2/Li2S) conversion gave rise to the shuttle of polysulfides, leading to poor Coulombic efficiency, the continuous loss of active material at the cathode, and irreversible capacity decay [47–50]. Various physical confinement [51,52] and chemical binding strategies [53–55] have been proposed. In this contribution, NGF/SNG was employed as conductive scaffolds to host sulfur to shed some light on the influence of N heteroatoms and their distribution on an electrode for multi-electron redox reactions. The cycling stability of the NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes was illustrated in Fig. 7 (a). The initial discharge capacity of 959 and 1039 mAh g−1 were achieved for NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes, respectively, at a current rate of 1.0 C (1.0 C = 1672 mAh g−1, based on sulfur). The discharge capacity of SNG-S cathodes remained 667 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles, which corresponded to a capacity fading of 35.8% and a decay rate of 0.09% per cycle. For NGF-S cathodes, only a capacity of 530 mAh g−1 was preserved after 400 cycles, which corresponded to a capacity decay of 44.7% and fading rate of 0.11% per cycle. Although NGF possessed larger SSA than SNG, SNG exhibited better S utilization rate and durability mainly induced by the difference in N heteroatom position. The detailed lithium ion storage performance of NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes was further illuminated by galvanostatic charge–discharge curves (Fig. 7b). Both NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes exhibited two typical voltage plateaus on discharge curves, corresponding to the reduction of sulfur into soluble lithium polysulfides (Li2S n , 4 < n < 8) at higher plateaus and liquid–solid conversion of polysulfides to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S at lower plateaus. The huge SSA and interconnected mesoporous graphene network made NGF and SNG suitable for accommodating the volume expansion from sulfur to Li2S. At the 3rd cycle, although the NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes contained the similar high voltage plateaus discharge behavior, the low voltage plateaus of NGF-S cathodes was lower and shorter than that of SNG-S cathodes. Such large polarization of NGF-S cathodes was induced by the limited exposure of N heteroatoms, which can hardly anchor the polysulfide intermediates for rapid redox conversions. However, SNG with surface enriched N atoms is more favorable and affords more anchoring sites [56–59]. Consequently, the SNG based cathode exhibited high sulfur utilization and cyclic stability. Both NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes displayed good rate performance (Fig. 7c). With the current density increased from 0.1 to 5.0 C, the capacity decreased gradually. The high-rate (5.0 C) capacity retention of 51.2% and 58.3% was realized for NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes, respectively. After harsh cycling at a high rate of 5.0 C, both NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes delivered a high capacity above 870 mAh g−1 when the current density returned to 0.2 C. The interconnected porous architecture improved electrolyte immersion and diffusion, rendering NGF-S and SNG-S cathodes with extraordinary rate performances. Due to the sluggish kinetics of redox chemistry on conducting interface, SNG with N enriched surface and higher electrical conductivity performed better than NGF at high rate. The cathode without any binders or metal current collectors was a promising design toward commercially viable Li−S battery [60]. In this work, flexible electrodes with NGF/SNG-S composites uniformly distributed into super-long CNT scaffolds at a high sulfur loading were fabricated. The areal sulfur loading amount in the flexible paper electrode reached 4.0 mg cm−2. Despite the absence of binder and the switch of aluminum foil to 3D CNT network current collector, the flexible SNG-S cathodes displayed an initial discharge capacity of 4.34 mAh cm−2 (1102 mAh g−1) at 0.2 C (Fig. 8 ). After one cycle activation, the discharge capacity maintained from 3.82 mAh cm−2 (970 mAh g−1) to 2.91 mAh cm−2 (740 mAh g−1) over 65 cycles at 1.0 C, which corresponded to 76.3% retention of the second cycle. In contrast, the initial discharge capacity of flexible NGF-S cathodes was 4.16 mAh cm−2 (1051 mAh g−1) at 0.2 C, which dropped to 3.62 mAh cm−2 (915 mAh g−1) at the second cycle, while only a capacity of 2.43 mAh cm−2 (615 mAh g−1) was preserved after 65 cycles at 1.0 C, which corresponded to 67.2% retention of the second cycle. The rational combination of ultra-long CNTs (highly efficient conductive networks) with 3D porous N-doped graphene (sulfur accommodation blocks) made areal capacities of flexible paper electrodes higher than pristine graphene/CNT flexible scaffolds reported [60]. The rational nitrogen doping of 3D porous graphene affords SNG with high electrical conductivity and the feasibility toward full exposure of active sites for advanced energy storage. 4 Conclusions When a nitrogen-doped graphene skin is deposited on the 3D porous graphene framework, the as-obtained SNG can inherit the morphology of templates and expose more surface N heteroatoms for energy storage. In contrast to the bulk doping of N into graphene framework in NGF, the SNG exhibits a high surface N content of 1.81 at%, enhanced electrical conductivity of 31 S cm−1, a large surface area of 1531 m2 g−1, low defect density with a low I D/I G ratio of 1.55 calculated from Raman spectrum profile, and a high oxidation peak of 532.7 °C in the oxygen atmospheres. This renders the SNG electrocatalyst with a small onset potential of NGF electrode of −0.140 V (14 mV less than that of NGF) and a large ORR current density. When the SNG is employed as the conductive scaffolds for Li−S batteries, a high initial capacity of 1039 mAh g−1 at 1.0 C, a small decay rate of 0.09% per cycle, and a high rate retention is achieved. The flexible SNG-S cathodes display an initial discharge capacity of 4.34 mAh cm−2 at 0.2 C when the sulfur loading is as high as 4.0 mg cm−2. Rather than N heteroatoms randomly distributed in a bulk conductive phase of NGF, the selective distribution of N heteroatoms on the surface of SNG affords the feasibility of effective exposure at the interfaces of the electrode/electrolyte. Such strategy can render more N heteroatoms to contact with oxygen feedstocks in ORR electrocatalysis, as well as polysulfide anchoring sites to retard the shuttle of polysulfides in a working Li−S battery. This work provides a rational nitrogen doping methodology with a view toward the design of surface hetero-junction nanostructures for vast applications in not only energy storage, electrocatalysis, but also heterogeneous catalysis, drug delivery, multiphase adsorption, and biosensors. coredata.dc:description: The introduction of nitrogen heteroatoms into carbon materials is a facile and efficient strategy to regulate their reactivities and facilitate their potential applications in energy conversion and storage. However, most of nitrogen heteroatoms are doped into the bulk phase of carbon without site selectivity, which significantly reduces the contacts of feedstocks with the active dopants in a conductive scaffold. Herein we proposed the chemical vapor deposition of a nitrogen-doped graphene skin on the 3D porous graphene framework and donated the carbon/carbon composite as surface N-doped grapheme (SNG). In contrast with routine N-doped graphene framework (NGF) with bulk distribution of N heteroatoms, the SNG renders a high surface N content of 1.81 at%, enhanced electrical conductivity of 31 S cm−1, a large surface area of 1531 m2 g−1, a low defect density with a low I D/I G ratio of 1.55 calculated from Raman spectrum, and a high oxidation peak of 532.7 °C in oxygen atmosphere. The selective distribution of N heteroatoms on the surface of SNG affords the effective exposure of active sites at the interfaces of the electrode/electrolyte, so that more N heteroatoms are able to contact with oxygen feedstocks in oxygen reduction reaction or serve as polysulfide anchoring sites to retard the shuttle of polysulfides in a lithium–sulfur battery. This work opens a fresh viewpoint on the manipulation of active site distribution in a conductive scaffolds for multi-electron redox reaction based energy conversion and storage.
